'Beta-adrenergic agonists' are a class of sympathomimetic agents which act upon
the beta adrenoreceptors. In general, pure beta-adrenergic agonists
have the opposite function of beta blockers. Beta adrenoreceptor agonist ligands
mimic the action of epinephrine and norepinephrine signaling in the heart, lungs
and smooth muscle tissue, with epinephrine being the highest affinity. The
activation of Î²1, Î²2 and Î²3 activates the enzyme, Adenylate cyclase. This in
turn leads to the activation of the secondary messenger Cyclic adenosine
monophosphate and induces smooth muscle relaxation and contraction of the
cardiac tissue.
